I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) will support the implementation of 
the Strategy for Promoting Safe and Environment-Friendly Agro-Based Value Chains in the 
Greater Mekong Subregion and Siem Reap Action Plan, which was endorsed by the agriculture 
ministers of the countries in the Greater Mekong Subregion (GMS) in September 2017.1 The TA 
will build on the achievements of phase 1 (2006–2012) and phase 2 (2012–2019) of the GMS 
Core Agriculture Support Program, help create enabling conditions, and strengthen the capacity 
for leveraging knowledge and investments in three priority areas: (i) climate-smart, inclusive, and 
gender-responsive agri-food value chains; (ii) food safety and quality systems; and (iii) climate-
adaptive agriculture in the context of the water–energy–food security nexus.2 
 
2.  The TA is strongly aligned with two operational priorities of the Strategy 2030 of the Asian 
Development  Bank  (ADB)—promoting  rural  development  and  food  security,  and  fostering 
regional cooperation and integration.3 It is also aligned with other operational priorities of ADB, 
such as reducing remaining poverty and inequities; accelerating progress in gender equality; 
tackling climate change, building climate and disaster resilience, and enhancing environmental 
sustainability; and strengthening governance and institutional capacity. The TA is included in the 
country operations business plans of the GMS countries.4 The TA will support GMS countries in 
their efforts to achieve the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), especially SDG 1, SDG 2, 
and SDG 13, and their nationally determined contributions under the Paris Agreement on Climate 
Change5. By bolstering capacity and enabling policies, and demonstrating innovative activities, 
the TA will contribute to the development of climate-smart agricultural investments and help 
realize the GMS vision of a more integrated, prosperous, and equitable subregion.6 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  Agriculture remains crucial to the GMS. More than 70% of the rural population directly 
depends on it for their livelihoods. Women make a vital contribution either as farmers, or 
agricultural laborers or entrepreneurs. Growth in agriculture has driven the rapid expansion of 
GMS economies since the 1990s and helped generate substantial commodity exports. Intra-GMS 
trade, including agricultural trade, grew from $5 billion (2.0% of total trade by GMS countries) in

trade volumes is high. 
 
4.  Infrastructure and capacity barriers along the agricultural value chains. Realizing 
the GMS vision of becoming a leading supplier of safe, quality, and climate-friendly agri-food 
products requires the removal of key infrastructure and capacity barriers along the value chains. 
Poor rural infrastructure, and many but fragmented small-scale farmers and small and medium-
sized agribusinesses have led to high inefficiencies in energy, water, and waste management 
along the value chain. Low investments in rural infrastructure resulted in high production costs, 
low crop yields, and low profitability for farmers and agribusinesses. An October 2019 report 
estimated that annual agricultural investments of $78.6 billion are needed to reduce the proportion 
of hungry people in Asia and the Pacific below 5% of the total population by 2030.8 Low awareness 
of  and  limited  access  to  affordable  financing  for  agribusinesses  and  female  agricultural 
entrepreneurs also continue to constrain growth, productivity, and competitiveness. 
 
5.  Food safety and quality concerns. Rising concerns about food scares and foodborne 
disease outbreaks have raised GMS consumer awareness of the importance of food safety and 
quality. The World Health Organization estimated that Southeast Asia had 150 million cases of 
foodborne illnesses each year from 2005 to 2015. The GMS is particularly prone to an increase 
in health risks from the rising volumes of informal trade in agri-food products across GMS borders 
with little control over quality and safety. Demand for safe and quality food by urban populations 
and tourists is growing in all GMS countries, but the lack of harmonized safety and quality 
assurance systems, ineffective control of transboundary animal diseases, and antimicrobial 
resistance constrain the GMS potential for agri-food exports. ADB support for sanitary and 
phytosanitary  measures  to  facilitate  GMS  trade  has  increased  the  technical  capacity  for 
surveillance and inspection and thus helps ensure plant and animal health as well as food safety,9 
but much needs to be done to promote cross-border cooperation and harmonization of sanitary 
and phytosanitary measures and practices. Boosting subregional cooperation under the One 
Health Initiative serves to maximize synergies between the human, animal, and environmental 
health systems; and to consolidate health security as a regional public good that benefits people 
across the subregion.10 
 
6.  Climate change and water–energy–food security nexus. Agriculture is the sector most 
vulnerable to climate change. In Thailand and Viet Nam, for example, ADB projected climate 
change to reduce rice yields by 50% and gross domestic product by 7% by 2050 if no concerted 
actions are taken.11 At the same time, Agriculture contributes significantly to climate change, 
accounting for about 14% of global greenhouse gas emissions. Projections suggest that annual 
greenhouse gas emissions from agriculture should be reduced by as much as 75% to limit global 
warming to below 2°C above pre-industrial temperatures. Agriculture is also the largest consumer 
of water, still accounting for nearly 70% of overall consumption despite growing urbanization and 
industrialization. By 2030, overall demand for water and energy is projected to increase by 40%, 
and agriculture is expected to produce 30%–50% more food. Water, energy, and food security

are thus interrelated, and interventions in one sector affect the other. Climate change and 
unsustainable agricultural practices are expected to worsen water scarcity, limit productivity, and 
reduce water availability in areas with high irrigation demand. Promoting agricultural adaptation 
in the context of the water–energy–food security nexus is therefore critical.  
 
7.  Market access. Weak policy and regulatory frameworks, poor knowledge and capacity of 
stakeholders,  ineffective  uptake  of  suitable  technology,  and  inadequate  financing  limit 
opportunities for the GMS to achieve better market access and economies of scale for safe, 
inclusive, and climate-smart agri-food products. Insufficient cooperation on cross-border issues, 
regional public goods, and harmonization of agri-food quality and safety standards also hampers 
progress in effectively integrating the subregion into global agribusiness markets. 
 
8.  Overcoming these barriers requires targeted capacity building; policy support to mobilize 
investments  in  inclusive,  climate-smart,  and  gender-responsive  agri-food  value  chains; 
awareness of options to access sustainable and affordable financing for small and medium-sized 
agribusinesses; and measures to harmonize food safety and quality standards. Introducing 
climate-adaptive  agricultural  practices  and  technology  is  critical  to  accommodate  multiple 
objectives in the water–energy–food security nexus. 
 
9.  Core Agriculture Support Program. The two phases of the Core Agriculture Support 
Program provide a sound basis for further regional cooperation on knowledge sharing and 
dialogue; agri-food policy initiatives and analytical work for better governance, efficiency, and 
equity; search for potential agri-food investments; and inputs for preparation of project concept 
papers and flagship knowledge products. Key successes of phase 1 were (i) greater technical 
capacity to implement sanitary and phytosanitary measures, (ii) the GMS Agriculture Information 
Network Service, and (iii) a trade facilitation study on customs and quarantine procedures at GMS 
borders. Phase 2 focused on (i) food safety and trade facilitation, (ii) climate-friendly agriculture, 
and  (iii)  bioenergy  and  biomass  management.  It  also  supported  agricultural  research  and 
technology, private sector involvement, and institutional mechanisms. 
 
10.  After assessing progress achieved under the Core Agriculture Support Program, the GMS 
Working Group on Agriculture (WGA), at its 16th Annual Meeting held in Louangphabang in June 
2019, prioritized six themes for support from ADB and other development partners:12 (i) promoting 
green, inclusive, and gender-responsive agri-food value chains; (ii) facilitating climate-smart 
agribusiness  financing;  (iii)  enhancing  food  safety  and  quality  standards,  certification,  and 
traceability; (iv) improving cross-border animal health and value chains; (v) managing water and 
soil for enhanced food security in a changing climate; and (vi) adapting agriculture to climate 
change in the context of the water–energy–food security nexus. 
 
11.  Through targeted demonstration activities, and policy, advisory, and knowledge support, 
the TA will help identify transactions and build a pipeline of investment projects for ADB and the 
private sector with a focus on climate-smart agriculture,13 agribusiness, horticulture, and livestock

agribusiness value chains by fostering collaboration between investment projects and the TA. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
12.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: GMS vision of being a leading supplier of safe 
and climate-friendly agri-food products realized (footnotes 1 and 12). The TA will have the 
following outcome: GMS investments in and capacity for climate-friendly, safe, and sustainable 
agri-food value chains increased.14 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
13.  The TA will take a holistic approach and enhance ADB’s value addition by promoting high-
level technology, novel knowledge products, and integrated solutions. It will (i) target government 
officials, farmers, and agribusinesses; and (ii) develop enabling policies to support private sector 
investments and select the best available technology for demonstration. By assessing how each 
GMS country responds to challenges, the TA will deliver three outputs, drawing on lessons and 
good practices from other countries and minimizing risks encountered in past and current efforts.15 
 
14.  Output 1: Climate-friendly, inclusive, and gender-responsive agri-food value chains 
and agribusinesses strengthened. This output will build the capacity for implementing climate-
smart  agriculture,  demonstrating  innovative  technology,  and  helping  mobilize  agribusiness 
financing. The sub-output of promoting green, inclusive, and gender-responsive agri-food value 
chains  will  (i) identify  policies  and  measures  to  promote  clean  energy  and  reduce  water 
consumption, food losses, and waste in some agri-food value chains, while effectively integrating 
gender concerns; (ii) strengthen the technical and institutional capacity of smallholders and 
agribusinesses along the value chain, particularly women farmers and entrepreneurs, for climate-
smart  agriculture, green  supply  chain  management,  agribusiness  skills,  and  value  addition 
through public–private partnerships; and (iii) conduct studies on green supply chain management 
(e.g., nitrogen use efficiency, green water management, and renewable and bioenergy for post-
harvest operations) in key agri-food value chains. The sub-output of facilitating climate-smart 
agribusiness financing will (i) propose measures to improve the financial preparedness of small 
and medium-sized agribusinesses, focusing on creating jobs for women; (ii) build technical and 
institutional  capacity  for  green  financing  options  for  agribusinesses;  and  (iii)  conduct 
demonstrations to guide agribusinesses in adopting low-carbon manufacturing practices. The TA 
will  organize  fairs  to  introduce  GMS  agribusinesses  to  investors  and  facilitate  knowledge 
exchange among participating agribusinesses. 
 
                                                
14 The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
15 Since short-term investment priorities tend to override long-term agricultural sustainability concerns, the TA will 
involve and extend assistance to planning and finance ministries, in addition to agriculture ministries. As government 
interest in borrowing to tackle food safety and quality issues is limited in the GMS, the TA will collaborate with the 
private sector to increase its awareness of safety and quality risks to long-term sustainability because of the changing 
climate. In view of declining overseas development assistance for environmental issues in the GMS, especially by 
development partners that were involved in previous phases, the TA will mobilize resources from a broader network 
of potential funding sources, including ADB’s own trust funds. Building the capacity of the GMS countries for the 
effective use of food safety and quality assessment tools is a long-term process that would require considerable 
additional resources and commitment by national development agencies. Knowledge sharing and capacity building 
will continue, but efforts need to also focus on field demonstrations to strengthen technical and institutional capacity 
and to assess options to create an enabling policy environment to mobilize and de-risk private sector investments.

5 
15.  Output 2: Harmonized crop and livestock safety and quality systems adopted. Key 
activities relating to food safety and quality standards, certification, and traceability include 
support for (i) harmonizing GMS policies and standards on food safety and quality assurance, 
certification  (e.g.,  organic,  good  agricultural  practices,  good  manufacturing  practices,  and 
geographic indications), accreditation, surveillance, and laboratories; (ii) setting up a platform to 
aid  information  exchange,  coordination,  and  food  risk  communication  strategies;  and 
(iii) demonstrating the use of digital technology (e.g., artificial intelligence, the Internet of Things,16 
and blockchain) for food traceability and quality assurance to promote domestic and regional 
trade, and ensure compliance with international food safety systems. Activities to improve cross-
border animal health and value chains include (i) enhancing policies and legislation on livestock, 
livestock products, and feed control; (ii) strengthening capacity for animal health workers to 
improve service delivery, control transboundary animal diseases, zoonoses, and antimicrobial 
resistance; and (iii) demonstrating the use of digital technology for livestock identification and 
traceability to ensure compliance with international safety and quality assurance systems. The TA 
will promote close synergies in activity planning with proposed investment to improve GMS cross-
border livestock health and value chains in Cambodia, the Lao People’s Democratic Republic, 
and Myanmar. Collaboration between the GMS countries and the Association of Southeast Asian 
Nations Food Safety network will be strengthened. 
 
16.  Output 3: Climate-adaptive agriculture in the context of the water–energy–food 
security nexus enhanced. Key activities include (i) preparing subregional assessments to 
prioritize activities critical to producing more food per drop of water; (ii) training government staff 
on climate-resilient soil and water management options, and water accounting in climate change 
scenarios; and (iii) conducting studies on climate-adaptive water management. Activities relating 
to the water–energy–food security nexus include (i) establishing a GMS platform to (a) conduct 
policy dialogues on options to reduce water, energy, carbon, and environmental footprints of 
agricultural practices; (b) align sector policies; and (c) identify low-cost options to make agri-food 
systems resilient to climate change; (ii) integrating nexus thinking in the climate change action 
plans of agriculture and related ministries, and in project design; and (iii) conducting studies on 
agricultural adaptation that proactively consider the water–energy–food security nexus (e.g., solar 
irrigation and agricultural waste to energy for food processing). 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
17.  The TA is estimated to cost $3.75 million, of which (i) $3.00 million will be financed on a 
grant basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF 6); and (ii) $0.75 million will be 
financed on a grant basis by the Climate Change Fund.17 The six GMS governments will provide 
counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, office space, and other in-kind contributions. 
Based on TA progress and needs, additional funds may be provided annually or in alternate years, 
including from cofinancing sources and ADB-administered trust funds. The key expenditure items 
are listed in Appendix 2.

animals or people that are provided with unique identifiers and the ability to transfer data over a network without 
requiring human-to-human or human-to-computer interaction.

D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
18.  ADB will administer the TA.18 The Environment, Natural Resources, and Agriculture 
Division  of  ADB’s  Southeast  Asia  Department  will  lead  the  overall  TA  implementation  in 
collaboration with the WGA and its national support units, as well as the GMS Secretariat. National 
staff from the resident missions will be closely involved in the implementation and invited to some 
WGA meetings. ADB will select, supervise, and evaluate consultants; and provide staff to act as 
resource persons in the workshops. The WGA focal points will oversee the work of consultants in 
demonstrating small-scale climate-smart agriculture interventions and technology. All activities 
will be screened to ensure minimal or no adverse social or environmental impacts as per the ADB 
Safeguards Policy Statement (2009). Procurement will follow the ADB Procurement Policy (2017, 
as amended from time to time) and its associated project administration instructions or staff 
instructions. Procured goods and assets will be turned over or disposed following ADB processes. 
 
19.  Knowledge products, including gender-specific reports, targeted at government officials, 
researchers, and development partners will be prepared for the WGA annual meetings and the 
agriculture ministers’ meetings. A limited number of copies of selected reports will be printed in 
English, if demanded, and in the local language, as needed. The developed knowledge reports 
will include an understanding of the differential needs, opportunities, and experiences of male and 
female and/or micro and small-scale farmers. Agriculture information portals will be developed as 
part of the GMS Secretariat’s website.19 Online communities on social media platforms will be 
created and will be deactivated within 3 months of the TA completion date. The implementation 
arrangements are summarized in the table.

Key Activities with Milestones 
1.  Climate-friendly, inclusive, and gender-responsive agri-food value chains and 
agribusinesses strengthened (Q2 2020–Q3 2024) 
1.1  Sub-output 1: Green, inclusive, and gender-responsive agri-food value chains promoted 
1.1.1  Identify the differential needs and opportunities of female and male farmers and farmers with 
micro, small, and medium-sized farms for enhancing energy efficiency; promoting renewable 
energy; and reducing water consumption, and food loss and waste along key agri-food value 
chains 
1.1.2  Conduct training and workshops on climate-smart agriculture, GSCM, and value addition  
1.1.3  Implement demonstration activities on GSCM (e.g., nitrogen fertilizer management and green 
water management), including interventions focusing on job creation for women 
1.2  Sub-output 2: Financing for climate-smart agribusinesses facilitated 
1.2.1  Assess differential barriers for the financial preparedness of micro, small, and medium-sized 
agribusinesses owned by men and women. 
1.2.2  Conduct training on green financing options for small and medium-sized agribusinesses, including 
marketing and business planning to improve financial preparedness 
1.2.3  Test incentive scheme for small and medium-sized agribusinesses to adopt climate-friendly 
practices 
2.  Harmonized crop and livestock safety and quality systems adopted (Q4 2020–Q1 2024) 
2.1  Sub-output 1: Food safety and quality standards, certification, and traceability enhanced 
2.1.1  Review and identify good practices and codes of conduct on standards and systems related to 
(i) good practices for crops, livestock, and aquaculture; (ii) food and livestock safety and quality 
assurance; (iii) certification and accreditation; (iv) surveillance and information systems and 
laboratories; and (v) use of advanced digital technology for food traceability 
2.1.2  Assist in the certification and establishment of quality assurance systems for domestic and 
regional trade, and compliance with food safety standards; and conduct training for relevant 
stakeholders, including women-owned agribusinesses 
2.1.3  Conduct demonstrations on the use of high-level technology (e.g., artificial intelligence, the 
Internet of Things, and blockchain) for food traceability and quality assurance systems

10  Appendix 1 
2.2  Sub-output 2: Cross-border animal health and value chains improved 
2.2.1  Conduct consultations with agriculture ministries to review and strengthen food and/or feed 
safety policies and regulations on the harmonization of standards for livestock and livestock 
products; and on feed control, traceability, and surveillance 
2.2.2  Provide training for relevant stakeholders on livestock product safety and quality, including 
control of transboundary animal diseases and antimicrobial resistance, and value addition 
2.2.3  Conduct studies on digital technology for livestock traceability and disease monitoring 
(e.g., reusable reticular cattle identification systems and the Internet of Things) 
3.  Climate-adaptive agriculture in the context of the water–energy–food security nexus 
enhanced (Q2 2020–Q1 2025) 
3.1  Sub-output 1: Water and soil for enhanced food security in a changing climate managed 
3.1.1  Consult  with  stakeholders,  including  government  staff,  the  private  sector,  civil  society 
organizations, women’s groups, and other vulnerable farmers, to prioritize activities critical to 
produce more food per drop of water and make agricultural systems resilient to climate change 
impacts 
3.1.2  Train government staff on water accounting in various climate scenarios, early warning systems, 
and climate-adaptive water management options in agriculture 
3.1.3  Conduct studies on climate-smart water and soil management practices for scale-up in investment 
projects 
3.2  Sub-output 2: Agriculture in the context of the water–energy–food security nexus 
adapted 
3.2.1  Create a GMS platform for climate-smart agriculture to conduct policy dialogues on adaptation 
and the water–energy–food security nexus, and identify measures to reduce water, energy, and 
carbon footprints of agricultural practices 
3.2.2  Train government staff in integrating nexus thinking in the design of projects, and in 
mainstreaming water–energy–food security nexus concerns in the climate change action plans 
of agriculture ministries 
3.2.3  Conduct studies that proactively consider the water–energy–food security nexus
